item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Soldiers Killed in Rebel Attack
item.description: At least 15 were killed in an ambush, a military official said, and the Shabab rebel group claimed responsibility on its online radio station.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: New Crop of Immigrants in Parliament Is Seen as Reflection of Canada
item.description: The Liberals’ victory at the polls last month is being seen by many, including immigrants newly elected to Parliament, as affirmation of Canadians’ belief in “a welcoming and accommodating nation.”
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Melissa Renwick/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A Muslim woman walking into a school to cast her ballot last month.

item.title: U.N. Leader Pledges to Reveal Donor Data
item.description: A month after a former leader was accused of corruption, the president of the United Nations General Assembly said he would make public what funds he receives from government and private donors.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Payout for Saudi’s ‘Secret Wife’
item.description: A British judge ruled that the woman, Janan Harb, 68, should receive more than $23 million and two apartments in London that had been promised to her by King Fahd.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China, Taiwan and a Meeting After 66 Years
item.description: President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan is to confer with President Xi Jinping of China in Singapore on Saturday, according to statements from both.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan is serving the final months of his second and last term as president.

item.title: Flash Was Detected as Russian Jet Broke Apart, U.S. Military Officials Say
item.description: The officials said satellite images of the flash were the first indication that the plane had exploded, because of either a bomb or the ignition of a fuel tank.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Sinai Province of the Islamic State
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Russian Ministry for Emergency Situations, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Russian crews collected the personal belongings of passengers on the Metrojet flight on Tuesday on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt

item.title: Backlash Against U.S. in Iran Seems to Gather Force After Nuclear Deal
item.description: Arrests of suspected American spies, anti-American billboards, and even the abrupt closure of a knockoff K.F.C. restaurant have signaled a backlash.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A K.F.C. knockoff in Tehran on Tuesday after it was closed by the police.

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: John Kerry Confronts Human Rights as He Zips Through Central Asia
item.description: The secretary of state’s four-day tour of the five “Stans” of the former Soviet Union has been an experiment in both power-balancing and sleep deprivation.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov of Turkmenistan, center at back, met with Secretary of State John Kerry at the Oguzkhan Presidential Palace in Ashgabat on Tuesday.

item.title: Ahmad Chalabi and the Legacy of De-Baathification in Iraq
item.description: While the decision to bar members of Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party from top government jobs was made by the United States, Mr. Chalabi, who died Tuesday, became the policy’s champion.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Ahmad Chalabi, at his home in Baghdad, watched the trial of Saddam Hussein in December 2005.

item.title: Britain Will Present Legislation to Increase Oversight of Surveillance
item.description: The draft legislation, known as the Investigatory Powers Bill, aims to streamline surveillance powers and retain public confidence that privacy will be protected.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: China Burns Much More Coal Than Reported, Complicating Climate Talks
item.description: China has been using up to 17 percent more coal a year than reported. By some estimates, that means almost a billion more tons of carbon dioxide released annually.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A train carrying coal passed by a coal-powered steam engine in March at a station in Shixi, a town in southern China.

item.title: New U.S.-Backed Alliance to Counter ISIS in Syria Falters
item.description: Ten days of interviews and front-line visits made clear that an alliance entrusted with beating jihadists in northern Syria faces daunting political and logistical challenges.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: A Kurdish militia fighter rested last week on the eastern banks of the Euphrates River. Islamic State militants fire on Kurdish bases from across the river.

item.title: Your Morning Briefing: China-Taiwan Meeting, Volkswagen Emissions
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day in Asia.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA SHANNON
item.media:description: A woman walked past an ad in China, where President Xi Jinping announced Tuesday that a 6.5 percent target had been set for annual economic growth from 2016 to 2020.

item.title: Who’s Involved in the Metrojet Crash Investigation
item.description: A complex web of national and business interests and the agendas and motives of individuals and terrorist groups intersect in the inquiry into the crash on the Sinai Peninsula.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.media:credit: Maxim Grigoriev/Russian Emergency Ministry, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Vladimir Puchkov, left, Russia's emergency situations minister, with other officials on Sunday at the site of the Metrojet crash on the Sinai Peninsula in Egypt.

item.title: Michelle Obama, With Conan O’Brien, Visits Troops in Qatar
item.description: Service members at Al Udeid Air Base appreciated the first lady’s visit, which also includes Jordan and is focused on education for adolescent girls.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Conan O'Brien introduced Michelle Obama to armed service members stationed at Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar on Tuesday.

item.title: 20 Years After Rabin, Israeli Politics Have Shifted
item.description: Decades ago, Israelis were either for or against giving territory to Palestinians, experts said. But now, Israelis are said to be in “an age of pragmatism.”
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A rally at Rabin Square in Tel Aviv on Saturday marked 20 years since the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel.

item.title: Fear and Silence in Bangladesh as Militants Target Intellectuals
item.description: The killing of two publishers over the weekend deepened the feeling of dread among Bangladeshis in the cross hairs of Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Bangladeshis protested after the killing of Faisal Arefin Dipan, a publisher of secular books, in Dhaka.

item.title: Romania Places the Heart of a Queen in Her Castle
item.description: Queen Marie, who died in 1938, had her heart placed in a small silver coffin, which was moved from a museum in Bucharest, Romania, to the room in her castle where she died.
item.dc:creator: KIT GILLET
item.media:description: A Romanian honor guard carried the silver coffin containing the heart of Queen Marie of Romania as it was moved on Tuesday from a museum in Bucharest to the castle where she died.

item.title: Serbia and Croatia, in Rare Cooperation, Provide Trains for Migrants
item.description: In the absence of an effective plan by the European Union, the arrangement was an unusual effort by nations to work together to address the humanitarian crisis.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW BRUNWASSER

item.title: Vatican’s Financial Troubles Run Deep, According to New Book
item.description: “Merchants in the Temple,” a new book by Gianluigi Nuzzi, describes a nest of greed, cronyism and mismanagement at the Vatican.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:description: Pope Francis, back center, in St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican on Tuesday. Two new books explore the Vatican's finances.
